sen.j: 唐崎神社（からさきじんじゃ）は、滋賀県大津市にある神社。
sen.e: Karasaki-jinja Shrine is a shrine in Otsu City, Shiga Prefecture.
Karasaki-jinja Shrine is a shrine in Otsu City, Shiga Prefecture.
Karasaki-jinja Shrine is a shrine in Otsu City, Shiga Prefecture.

sen.j: 日吉大社の摂社の一つである。
sen.e: It is one of the Hiyoshi-taisha Sessha shrines (auxiliary shrines dedicated to a deity closely-related to that of a main shrine)
It is one of the Hiyoshi-taisha Sessha Shrines (auxiliary shrines dedicated to a deity closely-related to that of a main shrine)
It is one of the Hiyoshi-taisha Sessha Shrines (auxiliary shrines dedicated to a deity closely-related to that of a main shrine)

sen.j: 琵琶湖西岸に位置する。
sen.e: It is located on the west coast of Lake Biwa.
It is located on the west coast of Lake Biwa.
It is located on the west coast of Lake Biwa.

sen.j: 境内は滋賀県指定史跡になっている。
sen.e: The precinct is a historic site designated by Shiga Prefecture.
The precinct is a historic site designated by Shiga Prefecture.
The precinct is a historic site designated by Shiga Prefecture.

sen.j: 日吉大社の社伝によれば、舒明天皇6年（633年）、琴御館宇志丸宿禰がこの地に居住し「唐崎」と名附けたという。
sen.e: The tradition of Hiyoshi-taisha Shrine says that Ushimaro no Sukune of the Kotonomitachi family lived here and named the region 'Karasaki' in 633.
The tradition of Hiyoshi-taisha Shrine says that Ushimaro no Sukune of the Kotonomitachi family lived here and named the region 'Karasaki' in 633.
The tradition of Hiyoshi-taisha Shrine says that Ushimaro no Sukune of the Kotonomitachi family lived here and named the region 'Karasaki' in 633.

sen.j: 祭神の女別當命は宇志丸宿禰の妻である。
sen.e: The enshrined deity Wakesuki Hime no Mikoto is his wife.
The enshrined deity Wakesuki Hime no Mikoto is his wife.
The enshrined deity Wakesuki Hime no Mikoto is his wife.

sen.j: 当社は持統天皇の時代に創建されたと伝えられる。
sen.e: The shrine is said to have been founded during the age of Empress Jito.
The shrine is said to have been founded during the age of Empress Jito.
The shrine is said to have been founded during the age of Empress Jito.

sen.j: かつては「女別当社」と呼ばれ、婦人病に霊験ありとして広く信仰を集めた。
sen.e: It used to be called 'Onna-betto-sha Shrine', and was widely believed to be wonder-working for women's diseases.
sen.cmt: 「女別当社」の読み方を唐崎神社に問い合わせましたが、正確にはわからないとのことでした。
sen.e: It used to be called 'Onna-betto-sha Shrine', and was widely believed to be wonder-working for women's diseases.
It used to be called 'Onna-betto-sha Shrine', and was widely believed to be wonder-working for women's diseases.

sen.j: 境内には、宇志丸宿禰が植えたのに始まるとされる「唐崎の松」がある。
sen.e: In the precinct is 'Karasaki no Matsu' (the pine at Karasaki), which is said to have been planted by Ushimaro no Sukune.
In the precinct is 'Karasaki no Matsu' (the pine at Karasaki), which is said to have been planted by Ushimaro no Sukune.
In the precinct is 'Karasaki no Matsu' (the pine at Karasaki), which is said to have been planted by Ushimaro no Sukune.

sen.j: 境内から琵琶湖を背景に唐崎の松を描いた歌川広重の「唐崎の夜雨」で知られており、近江八景に選ばれている。
sen.e: Karasaki no yau' (Night Rain at Karasaki) by Hiroshige UTAGAWA, in which Karasaki no Matsu was depicted against the background of Lake Biwa from the precinct, is well known and classified as one of Omi Hakkei (the Eight Views of Lake Biwa)

Karasaki no yau' (Night Rain at Karasaki) by Hiroshige UTAGAWA, in which Karasaki no Matsu was depicted against the background of Lake Biwa from the precinct, is well known and classified as one of Omi Hakkei (the Eight Views of Lake Biwa)

Karasaki no yau' (Night Rain at Karasaki) by Hiroshige UTAGAWA, in which Karasaki no Matsu was depicted against the background of Lake Biwa from the precinct, is well known and classified as one of Omi Hakkei (the Eight Views of Lake Biwa)

sen.j: 宇志丸宿禰が植えた初代の松は天正9年（1581年）に大風で倒れ、現在の松は天正19年（1591年）に植えられた2代目である。
sen.e: The first pine tree planted by Ushimaro no Sukune fell over due to wind in 1581, and the present pine tree is the second one planted in 1591.
The first pine tree planted by Ushimaro no Sukune fell over due to wind in 1581, and the present pine tree is the second one planted in 1591.
The first pine tree planted by Ushimaro no Sukune fell over due to wind in 1581, and the present pine tree is the second one planted in 1591.
